thread.title: Fed Hikes 25 Basis Points, Signals Two More Hikes in 2017
thread.title_full: Fed Hikes 25 Basis Points, Signals Two More Hikes in 2017

author: Aaron Hankin
title: Fed Hikes 25 Basis Points, Signals Two More Hikes in 2017
text:
Fed Increases Interest Rates at March Meeting By Aaron Hankin | March 15, 2017 â€” 2:47 PM EDT 
As expected the U.S. Federal Reserve raised the fed funds rate by 25 basis points today, the second hike in three months and just the third in eleven years. "In view of realized and expected labor market conditions and inflation, the Committee decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate to 3/4 to 1 percent," the FOMC said in its statement. 
The Fed did not deviate much from its January statement saying "gradual" changes in policy are expected but did acknowledge that inflation levels are becoming a factor in future policy decisions. "The Committee will carefully monitor actual and expected inflation developments relative to its symmetric inflation goal," the FOMC said. 
After upbeat February economic data investors had fully priced in the move by the Fed and the focus was on the future interest rate path, which the Fed left at three for 2017 and three for 2018. Some participants were calling for four hikes in 2017. (See also: Is the Fed Behind the Curve? ) Credio | Graphiq 
The slightly dovish tone from the Fed has helped equity markets, with major indices up 0.5 percent. Bond yields have fallen, the benchmark 10-year yield has fallen seven basis points to 2.535 percent today and the U.S. dollar is weaker across the board losing 1 percent against the yen and the Euro. (See also: The Fed, Wall Street, Economists Love Rate Hikes ) 
The Fed projected gross domestic product ( GDP ) to hold steady at 2.1 percent in 2017, unemployment to finish the year at 4.5 percent and PCE inflation to reach 1.9 percent. See Fed projections here . 
Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari dissented, saying he was in favor of leaving rates unchanged. 
Stay tuned for further analysis after Federal Chairperson Janet Yellen's conference. Trending
